instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.03amps
threads.message:
Board looks like its been thru a few shops, GPU seems to have some heard near by.

Found short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, both <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> and <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> were shorted, I replaced those and short is gone, but not the board is stuck at 20v 0.03amps
I checked all rails on page 120 and 121 (that's how I found the above short) now there are not shorts but no power, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is obviously 0v.

Any pointers are appreciated, reballing that <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> took some time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.03amps
threads.message:
If board was messed up like that, could be just waste of time.

Did you check basic voltages and signals for power on sequence?
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
What about <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> and RTC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.03amps
threads.message:
[LEFT]PP[COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v

Taking a closer look it seems like some work was done on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> I think that is the PCH, or the previews shot that worked on it removed it for some reason and this may not even be the correct one.

Please advice.[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.03amps
threads.message:
I don't think is a good idea to continue.

However, you can check RTC signals.
Also trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
If present, check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.03amps
threads.message:
When I trigger [LEFT][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]
  [LEFT][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> does NOT pulse

I think this will be a good board... for parts LoL[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.03amps
threads.message:
Apart of PCH, looks like SMC problem too.
So good board for scrap...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.03amps
